column2: ABSTRACT
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column right-indent font-largest column-top line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-capital above-line-space

column2: Recent advances in Automatic Speech Recognition technology have
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column centered right-over aligned-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital

column2: put the goal of naturally sounding dialog systems within reach.
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: However, the improved speech recognition has brought to light
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: a new problem: as dialog systems understand more of what the
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line itemization headchar-lower

column2: user tells them, they need to be more sophisticated at responding
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: to the user. The issue of system response to users has been ex-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tensively studied by the natural language generation community,
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-comma

column2: though rarely in the context of dialog systems. We show how re-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: search in generation can be adapted to dialog systems, and how
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the high cost of hand-crafting knowledge-based generation systems
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: can be overcome by employing machine learning techniques.
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 1. DIALOG SYSTEMS AND GENERATION
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified font-largest aligned-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space itemization above-line-space

column2: Recent advances in Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) tech-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column left-indent indented-line line-space headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: nology have put the goal of naturally sounding dialog systems within
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column right-over hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: reach. <sup>1</sup> However, the improved ASR has brought to light a new
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified font-largest aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: problem: as dialog systems understand more of what the user tells
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: them, they need to be more sophisticated at responding to the user.
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: If ASR is limited in quality, dialog systems typically employ a
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital column-bottom

column2: ticular way, and a range of linguistic representations which can be
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified column-top headchar-lower

column2: used in accomplishing these tasks. Many systems have been built
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: using NLG technology, including report generators [8, 7], system
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: description generators [10], and systems that attempt to convince
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the user of a particular view through argumentation [20, 4].
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: In this paper, we claim that the work in NLG is relevant to dia-
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: log systems as well. We show how the results can be incorporated,
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower tailchar-comma

column2: and report on some initial work in adapting NLG approaches to di-
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: alog systems and their special needs. The dialog system we use is
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the AT&T Communicator travel planning system.We use machine
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: learning and stochastic approaches where hand-crafting appears to
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: be too complex an option, but we also use insight gained during
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: previous work on NLG in order to develop models of what should
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: be learned. In this respect, the work reported in this paper differs
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: from other recent work on generation in the context of dialog sys-
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tems [12, 16], which does not modularize the generation process
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: and proposes a single stochastic model for the entire process. We
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: start out by reviewing the generation architecture (Section 2). In
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: Section 3, we discuss the issue of text planning for Communicator.
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital tailchar-period

column2: In Section 4, we summarize some initial work in using machine
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: learning for sentence planning [19]. Finally, in Section 5 we sum-
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen column-bottom

column2: system-initiative dialog strategy in which the dialog system prompts marize work using stochastic tree models in generation [2].
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column right-indent font-largest column-top headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: the user for specific information and then presents some informa-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tion to the user. In this paradigm, the range of user input at any time
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 single-column right-indent aligned-line headchar-lower column-bottom

column2: is limited (thus facilitating ASR), and the range of system output at
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified column-top headchar-lower

column2: any time is also limited. However, such interactions are not very
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: natural. In a more natural interaction, the user can supply more and
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: different information at any time in the dialog. The dialog system
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: must then support a mixed-initiative dialog strategy. While this
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: strategy places greater requirements on ASR, it also increases the
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: range of system responses and the requirements on their quality in
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: terms of informativeness and of adaptation to the context.
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: For a long time, the issue of system response to users has been
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: studied by the Natural Language Generation (NLG) community,
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower tailchar-comma

column2: though rarely in the context of dialog systems. What have emerged
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: from this work are a “consensus architecture” [17] which modu-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: larizes the large number of tasks performed during NLG in a par-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen above-double-space above-line-space

column2: The work reported in this paper was partially funded by DARPA
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column left-indent indented-line line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: contract MDA972-99-3-0003.
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column right-indent hanged-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space
page=0 xpos=0 ypos=9 left-column right-indent font-smallest aligned-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space tailchar-period column-bottom

column2: 2. TEXT GENERATION ARCHITECTURE
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column right-indent font-largest column-top itemization above-line-space
page=0 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column left-indent right-indent indented-line shorter-tail line-space tailchar-period

column2: NLG is conceptualized as a process leading from a high-level
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column left-indent aligned-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: communicative goal to a sequence of communicative acts which
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: accomplish this communicative goal. A communicative goal is a
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: goal to affect the user’s cognitive state, e.g., his or her beliefs about
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the world, desires with respect to the world, or intentions about
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: his or her actions in the world. Following (at least) [13], it has
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: been customary to divide the generation process into three phases,
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-comma

column2: the first two of which are planning phases. Reiter [17] calls this
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: architecture a “consensus architecture” in NLG.
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: During text planning, a high-level communicative goal is
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space

column2: broken down into a structured representation of atomic com-
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column left-indent indented-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: municative goals, i.e., goals that can be attained with a single
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column left-indent aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: communicative act (in language, by uttering a single clause).
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column left-indent aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: The atomic communicative goals may be linked by rhetori-
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column left-indent aligned-line headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: cal relations which show how attaining the atomic goals con-
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column left-indent aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tributes to attaining the high-level goal.
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column left-indent right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: During sentence planning, abstract linguistic resources are
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=9 right-column left-indent hanged-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space

column2: chosen to achieve the atomic communicative goals. This
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=9 right-column left-indent indented-line headchar-lower

column2: includes choosing meaning-bearing lexemes, and how the
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=9 right-column left-indent aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: meaning-bearing lexemes are connected through abstract gram-
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=9 right-column left-indent right-over aligned-line longer-tail headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: matical constructions (basically, lexical predicate-argument
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=9 right-column left-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower page-bottom

column2: __Figure 1__
column3: page=1 xpos=-1 ypos=-4 single-column full-justified box page-top figure-area above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Figure 1: Architecture of a dialog system with natural language generation
column3: page=1 xpos=2 ypos=0 single-column centered left-indent right-indent indented-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space string-figure headchar-capital column-bottom above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: structure and modification). As a side-effect, sentence plan-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=0 left-column left-indent column-top line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ning also determines sentence boundaries: there need not
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=0 left-column left-indent aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: be a one-to-one relation between elementary communicative
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=1 left-column left-indent aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: goals and sentences in the final text.
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=1 left-column left-indent right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-double-space above-line-space

column2: During realization, the abstract linguistic resources chosen
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=1 left-column left-indent hanged-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space

column2: during sentence planning are transformed into a surface lin-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=1 left-column left-indent indented-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: guistic utterance by adding function words (such as auxil-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column left-indent aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: iaries and determiners), inflecting words, and determining
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column left-indent aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: word order. This phase is not a planning phase in that it only
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column left-indent aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: executes decisions made previously, by using grammatical
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column left-indent aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: information about the target language. (Prosody assignment
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column left-indent aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: can be treated as a separate module which follows realization
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column left-indent aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: and which draws on all previous levels of representation. We
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column left-indent aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: do not discuss prosody further in this paper.)
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column left-indent right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Note that sentence planning and realization use resources spe-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column left-indent hanged-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen column-bottom

column2: 3. TEXT PLANNER
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=0 right-column right-indent font-largest column-top itemization above-line-space

column2: Based on observations from the travel domain of the Communi-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=0 right-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: cator system, we have categorized system responses into two types.
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=1 right-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: The first type occurs during the initial phase when the system is
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=1 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: gathering information from the user. During this phase, the high-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=1 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: level communicative goals that the system is trying to achieve are
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=1 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: fairly complex: the goals include getting the hearer to supply in-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=1 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: formation, and to explicitly or implicitly confirm information that
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the hearer has just supplied. (These latter goals are often motivated
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: by the still not perfect quality of ASR.) The second type occurs
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: when the system has obtained information that matches the user’s
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: requirements and the options (flights, hotel, or car rentals) need to
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: be presented to the user. Here, the communicative goal is mainly to
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: make the hearer believe a certain set of facts (perhaps in conjunc-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tion with a request for a choice among these options).
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: In the past, NLG systems typically have generated reports or
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital column-bottom

column2: cific to the target-language, while text planning is language-independent summaries, for which the high-level communicative goal is of the
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 single-column full-justified column-top headchar-lower column-bottom

column2: (though presumably it is culture-dependent).
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column right-indent column-top tailchar-period

column2: In integrating this approach into a dialog system, we see that the
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: dialog manager (DM) no longer determines surface strings to send
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: to the TTS system, as is often the case in current dialog systems.
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: Instead, the DM determines high-level communicative goals which
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: are sent to the NLG component. Figure 1 shows a complete archi-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tecture. An advantage of such an architecture is the possibility for
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: extended plug-and-play: not only can the entire NLG system be
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: replaced, but also modules within the NLG system, thus allowing
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: researchers to optimize the system incrementally.
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: The main objection to the use of NLG techniques in dialog sys-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: tems is that they require extensive hand-tuning of existing sys-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tems and approaches for new domains. Furthermore, because of
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the relative sophistication of NLG techniques as compared to sim-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: pler techniques such as templates, the hand-tuning requires spe-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: cialized knowledge of linguistic representations; hand-tuning tem-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: plates only requires software engineering skills. An approach based
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: on machine learning can provide a solution to this problem: it
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: draws on previous research in NLG and uses the same sophisti-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: cated linguistic representations, but it learns the domain-specific
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: rules that use these representation automatically from data. It is the
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: goal of our research to show that for dialog systems, approaches
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: based on machine learning can do as well as or outperform hand-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: crafted approaches (be they NLG- or template-based), while requir-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=9 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ing far less time for tuning. In the following sections, we summa-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=9 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: rize the current state of our research on an NLG system for the
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=9 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: Communicator dialog system.
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=9 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-capital tailchar-period column-bottom

column2: type “make the hearer/reader believe a given set of facts”, as it is
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified column-top headchar-lower

column2: in the second type of system response discussed above. We believe
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: that NLG work in text planning can be successfully adapted to bet-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ter plan these system responses, taking into account not only the
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: information to be conveyed but also the dialog context and knowl-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: edge about user preferences. We leave this to ongoing work.
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: In the first type of system response, the high-level communica-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: tive goal typically is an unordered list of high-level goals, all of
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: which need to be achieved with the next turn of the system. An ex-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ample is shown in Figure 2. NLG work in text planning has not ad-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: dressed such complex communicative goals in the past. However,
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-comma

column2: we have found that for the Communicator domain, no text planning
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: is needed, and that the sentence planner can act directly on a rep-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: resentation of the type shown in Figure 2, because the number of
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: goals is limited (to five, in our studies). We expect that further work
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: in other dialog domains will require an extension of existing work
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: in text planning to account better for communicative goals other
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: than those that simply aim to affect the user’s (hearer’s) beliefs.
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-double-space above-line-space

column2: __Figure 2__
column3: page=1 xpos=6 ypos=8 right-column centered left-indent right-indent box indented-line shorter-tail line-double-space line-space figure-area above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Figure 2: Sample text plan (communicative goals)
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=9 right-column centered left-indent right-indent hanged-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space string-figure headchar-capital page-bottom

column2: __Figure 3__
column3: page=2 xpos=1 ypos=-2 single-column left-indent right-indent box page-top figure-area above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Figure 3: Sample alternate realizations of the set of communicative goals shown in Figure 2 suggested by our sentence planner, with
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space string-figure headchar-capital

column2: human scores
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower above-double-space above-line-space

column2: __Figure 4__
column3: page=2 xpos=1 ypos=0 single-column left-indent right-indent box indented-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space figure-area above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Figure 4: Architecture of our sentence planner
column3: page=2 xpos=3 ypos=3 single-column centered left-indent right-indent indented-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space string-figure headchar-capital column-bottom above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 4. SENTENCE PLANNER
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column right-indent font-largest column-top line-blank-line line-double-space line-space itemization above-line-space

column2: The principal challenge facing sentence planning for dialog sys-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: tems is that there is no good corpus of naturally occurring interac-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tions of the type that need to occur between a dialog system and hu-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: man users. This is because of the not-yet perfect ASR and the need
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: for implicitly or explicitly confirming most or all of the informa-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tion provided by the user. In conversations between two humans,
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-comma

column2: communicative goals such as implicit or explicit confirmations are
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: rare, and thus transcripts of human-human interactions in the same
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: domain cannot be used for the purpose of learning good strategies
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: to attain communicative goals. And of course we do not want to
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: use transcripts of existing systems, as we want to improve on their
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: performance, not mirror it.
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: We have therefore taken the approach of randomly generating a
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: set of solutions and having human judges score each of the options.
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: Each turn of the system is, as described in Section 3, characterized
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: by a set of high-level goals such as that shown in Figure 2. In the
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: turns we consider, no text planning is needed. To date, we have
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: concentrated on the issue of choosing abstract syntactic construc-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tions (rather than lexical choice), so we map each elementary com-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: municative goal to a canonical lexico-syntactic structure (called a
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: DSyntS [11]). We then randomly combine these DSyntSs into
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: larger DSyntSs using a set of clause-combining operations iden-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tified previously in the literature [14, 18, 5], such as RELATIVE -
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: CLAUSE , CONJUNCTION , and MERGE . <sup>2</sup> The way in which the ele-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified font-largest aligned-line headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: mentary DSyntSs are combined is represented in a structure called
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the sp-tree. Each sp-tree is then realized using an off-the-shelf re-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: alizer, RealPro [9]. Some sample realizations for the same text plan
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: are shown in Figure 3, along with the average of the scores assigned
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: by two human judges.
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=9 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-double-space above-line-space

column2: <sup></sup> MERGE identifies the verbs and arguments of two lexico-syntactic
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=9 left-column centered left-indent font-largest longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-super

column2: structures which differ only in adjuncts. For example, you are flying
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=9 left-column full-justified headchar-lower

column2: from Newark and you are flying on Monday are merged to you are
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=9 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: flying from Newark on Monday.
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=9 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period column-bottom

column2: Using the human scores on each of the up to twenty variants per
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column left-indent column-top headchar-capital

column2: turn, we use RankBoost [6] to learn a scoring function which uses
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: a large set of syntactic and lexical features. The resulting sentence
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line itemization headchar-lower

column2: planner consists of two components: the sentence plan generator
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: (SPG) which generates candidate sentence plans and the sentence
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line

column2: plan ranker (SPR) which scores each one of them using the rules
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: learned by RankBoost and which then chooses the best sentence
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: plan. This architecture is shown in Figure 4.
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: We compared the performance of our sentence planner to a ran-
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: dom choice of sentence plans, and to the sentence plans chosen
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: as top-ranked by the human judges. The mean score of the turns
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: judged best by the human judges is 4.82 as compared with the
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: mean of 4.56 for the turns generated by our sentence planner, for
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: a mean difference of 0.26 (5%) on a scale of 1 to 5. The mean of
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line itemization headchar-lower

column2: the scores of the turns picked randomly is 2.76, for a mean differ-
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ence of 1.8 (36%). We validated these results in an independent
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: experiment in which 60 subjects evaluated different realizations for
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: a given turn [15]. (Recall that our trainable sentence planner was
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line itemization headchar-lower

column2: trained on the scores of only two human judges.) This evaluation
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: revealed that the choices made by our trainable sentence planner
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: were not statistically distinguishable from the choices ranked at the
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: top by the two human judges. More importantly, they were also not
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: distinguishable statistically from the current hand-crafted template-
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: based output of the AT&T Communicator system, which has been
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: developed and fine-tuned over an extended period of time (the train-
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: able sentence planner is based on judgments that took about three
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: person-days to make).
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 5. REALIZER
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column right-indent font-largest aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space itemization above-line-space

column2: At the level of the surface language, the difference in commu-
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=9 right-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: nicative intention between human-human travel advisory dialogs
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=9 right-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: and the intended dialogs is not as relevant: we can try and mimic
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=9 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the human-human transcripts as closely as possible. To show this,
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=9 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-comma

column2: we have performed some initial experiments using FERGUS (Flex-
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=9 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen page-bottom

column2: ible Empiricist-Rationalist Generation Using Syntax), a stochastic
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=0 left-column full-justified page-top headchar-lower

column2: surface realizer which incorporates a tree model and a linear lan-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=0 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: guage model [2]. We have developed a metric which can be com-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=0 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: puted automatically from the syntactic dependency structure of the
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=0 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: sentence and the linear order chosen by the realizer, and we have
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=0 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: shown that this metric correlates with human judgments of the fe-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=0 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: licity of the sentence [3]. Using this metric, we have shown that the
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=0 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: use of both the tree model and the linear language model improves
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=1 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the quality of the output of FERGUS over the use of only one or
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=1 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the other of these resources.
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=1 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: FERGUS was originally trained on the Penn Tree Bank cor-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=1 left-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: pus consisting of Wall Street Journal text (WSJ). The results on
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=1 left-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: an initial set of Communicator sentences were not encouraging,
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=1 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-comma

column2: presumably because there are few questions in the WSJ corpus,
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-comma

column2: and furthermore, specific constructions (including what as deter-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: miner) appear to be completely absent (perhaps due to a newspaper
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: style file). In an initial experiment, we replaced the linear language
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: model (LM) trained on 1 million words of WSJ by an LM trained
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: on 10,000 words of human-human travel planning dialogs collected
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: at CMU. This resulted in a dramatic improvement, with almost all
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: questions being generated correctly. Since the CMU corpus is rel-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: atively small for a LM, we intend to experiment with finding the
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: ideal combination of WSJ and CMU corpora. Furthermore, we are
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: currently in the process of syntactically annotating the CMU cor-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: pus so that we can derive a tree model as well. We expect further
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: improvements in quality of the output, and we expect to be able
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: to exploit the kind of limited lexical variation allowed by the tree
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: model [1].
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 6. CONCLUSION
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column right-indent font-largest aligned-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space itemization above-line-space

column2: We have discussed how work in NLG can be applied in the
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital

column2: development of dialog systems, and we have presented two ap-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: proaches to using stochastic models and machine learning in NLG.
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: Of course, the final justification for using a more sophisticated NLG
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: architecture must come from user trials of an integrated system.
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: However, we suspect that, as in the case of non-dialog NLG sys-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: tems, the strongest arguments in favor of NLG often come from
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: software engineering issues of maintainability and extensibility, which
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column right-over aligned-line longer-tail headchar-lower

column2: can be difficult to quantify in research systems.
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-double-space above-line-space
